Highly efficient MgF2 supported Co catalyst for cyclization reaction of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol Yanjie Chen Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft a Xinhui Sun Software Validation a Yuli Sha Validation a Xinjie Fang Validation a Wenyi Chu Conceptualization Resources Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Xin Wang Project administration Writing – review & editing b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, Heilongjiang, China School of Chemistry and Materials Science Heilongjiang University Harbin Heilongjiang 150080 China aSchool of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, Heilongjiang, China b Jiangnan University Medical Center, Wuxi, Jiangsu, 214002, China Jiangnan University Medical Center Wuxi Jiangsu 214002 China bJiangnan University Medical Center, Wuxi, Jiangsu, 214002, China ⁎ Corresponding author. A highly dispersed Co-based catalyst (termed as Co@MgF2-f-h) with strong metal-support interaction has been synthesized by using ammonium-fluoride (NH4F) hexamethylenetetramine (hmta) assisted hydrothermal method. The Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibited excellent performance for cyclization reaction of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol. Extensive techniques including as XRD, FESEM, TEM, HADDF-STEM-EDS and H2-TPR were conducted to reveal the reason for the enhanced performance of Co@MgF2-f-h for cyclization reaction of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol in comparison with those of reference catalysts (Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h, respectively) without using ammonium-fluoride and hexamethylenetetramine structure-directing agents. This study may endow a feasible guidance for the preparation of MgF2 supported Co catalysts with excellent performance for other catalytic reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co-based catalyst Support effect Particle size Cyclization reaction Strong metal-support interaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The nitrogenous heterocyclic compounds (imidazoles, thiazoles and azepines) are widely found in nature, and used in drugs due to their biological activities [1–4]. The synthesis of benzimidazole and its derivatives has attracted extensive attention. Because benzimidazole-based derivatives are crucial building blocks for the drug discovery because of their prominent biological activities, for instance, antiviral, antihypertensive, anti-inflammatory, antitumor, antimicrobial and antiulcer agents (Fig. 1 ) [5–7]. In addition, benzimidazoles are also using as functional materials and vital intermediates widely applied in organic reactions, such as the preparation of dyes, pigments, phosphorescent organic light-emitting diodes, optical brighteners, as well as high-temperature polymers [8–14]. Recently, some noble metal catalysts (Pd, Au, Ir) have been extensively applied in the cyclization reaction between o-nitroanilines and benzyl-alcohols to synthesize the corresponding benzimidazoles [15–17]. Although noble metal catalysts have revealed highly activity and selectivity in the cyclization reaction, their high price and low utilizable confine their widespread application in industry. Many of transition-metal catalysts (e.g. Ni, Co) have been explored as promising materials for synthetic reactions in redox processes owning to their earth-abundant, easily available, and inexpensive [18–26]. To date, although homogeneous transition metal catalysts have been extensively explored, many of them are difficult to separate, recycle and circulate due to their inherent disadvantages [28–31]. Therefore, direct synthesis of benzimidazoles via redox process catalyzed by heterogeneous transition metal catalysts is highly desirable. Supported metal catalysts, particularly Co-based catalysts, have exhibited good catalytic performance involving CO2 reduction reaction, hydrogenation reaction, ammonia synthesis, and so on [32–39]. Although significant advances have been made in catalyst synthesis, the particular interfacial structure and dispersion of active species fulfill a vital role in enhancing the performance of supported metal catalysts for catalytic reactions [40,61]. Therefore, it is particularly essential to further enhance the dispersion of Co and strengthen the metal-support interaction of support Co-based catalysts. Recently, numerous strategies have been proposed to improve dispersion of active species and inhibit their agglomeration, including microwave assisted synthesis, atomic layer deposition [41–46]. Hence, synthesis of Co-based catalysts with small size and highly dispersed of metallic Co, together with strong metal-support interaction to exclude the catalyst deactivation caused by thermal reaction are imperative. The Co-based catalysts with small size and high dispersity are favorable for adsorption of the reactants during cyclization process [47]. Accordingly, design and synthesis of high-efficiency Co-based catalysts with small size, high dispersity and strong metal-support interaction for cyclization reaction is essential. In this work, hierarchical MgF2 nanosheets supported metallic Co catalyst obtained through a hydrothermal process with the introduction of hmta and NH4F (designated as Co@MgF2-f-h) and a subsequent annealing treatment under air and reducing atmosphere. Compared with the Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h catalysts, the developed Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst revealed high catalytic performance in the cyclization of o-nitroanilines with benzyl-alcohols to direct synthesis of 2-arylbenzimidazoles. Various characterizations including FT-IR, SEM, TEM, HADDF-STEM, EDS-mapping, XRD, H2-TPR have demonstrated that the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibited high performance for cyclization reaction was ascribed to its small size and highly dispersion of metallic Co, as well as strong Co-MgF2 interaction. This work may also supply a novel guide for synthesis of the supported Co catalysts for other cyclization reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Hexamethylenetetramine (99.9%, A. R.), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate {Co(NO3)2·6H2O}, magnesium nitrate hexahydrate {Mg(NO3)2·6H2O}, and ammonium-fluoride (NH4F) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The other chemicals were purchased from Energy Chemical. 2.2 Preparation precursors of Co-MgF2-f-h, Co-MgF2-f and Co-MgO-h For Co-MgF2-f-h precursor: hmta (1.25 mmol) was dissolved in aqueous solution (30 mL), and aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.025 mmol) and Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.35 mmol) was added. Then, 5 mL aqueous solution of NH4F (0.75 mmol) was added above mixture solution slowly, and stirred for 2 h. Subsequently, the reaction solution was transferred into a hydrothermal reactor (50 mL), and kept at 100 °C for 12 h. After being naturally cooled down to RT, the generated light-salmon Co-MgF2-f-h particles were gathered via centrifugation, washed by water five times, and dried (80 °C, for 12 h). Co-MgF2-f precursor was synthesized similarly to the synthesis of Co-MgF2-f-h without adding hmta. After the hydrothermal reaction, the product was obtained under drying at 105 °C to remove the solvent. Co-MgO-h precursor was synthesized similarly to the synthesis of Co-MgF2-f-h without adding NH4F. 2.3 Preparation of Co@MgF2-f-h, Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h catalysts The obtained Co-MgF2-f-h, Co-MgF2-f and Co-MgO-h precursors were calcinated in Air at 550 °C for 5 h (3 °C/min), then, naturally cooled down to room temperature, the obtained samples were designated as Co3O4@MgF2-f-h, Co3O4@MgF2-f and Co3O4@MgO-h, respectively. For the reduced catalysts, the obtained Co3O4@MgF2-f-h, Co3O4@MgF2-f and Co3O4@MgO-h samples were reduced by the H2/Ar (10/90, vol/vol) at 650 °C (5 °C/min) for 2 h. After naturally cooled down to RT, three categories Co-based reduced catalysts were obtained, which were denoted as Co@MgF2-f-h, Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h, respectively. 2.4 Characterization FT-IR spectra (Perkin-Elmer Spectrum100 spectroscopy). TG-DSC (PerkinElmer STA 6000). XRD (Rigaku D/Max-3B X-ray diffractometer). SEM (JEOL JSM-5600LV). TEM and HAADF-STEM-EDS (JEM-F200). Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) (Builder PCA-1200), and the details was provided in the SI. 1HNMR (Bruker Ultrashield™ 400 MHz spectrometer). 2.5 Catalytic product analysis Add benzyl-alcohol (0.75 mmol), o-nitroaniline (0.25 mmol) and catalyst (30 mg) to a round bottom flask with toluene (5 mL) as a solvent under N2 gas protection. Then, stirring the reaction mixture at 110 °C and monitored by TLC. After the reaction, cooled down the reaction mixture to RT and remove the catalyst from the obtained mixture by a powerful magnet. Then aqueous solution (50 mL) was introduced to above mixture, and taken by the extracted (ethyl acetate), dried (anhydrous sodium sulfate), as well as further removed the solvent to gain the crude product. After that, the crude products were purified and characterized by 1HNMR . 3 Results and discussion Scheme 1 illustrate the synthetic route of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst with homogenous morphology. Initially, the catalyst precursor was obtained through a hydrothermal method, the Co-MgF2-f-h was synthesized from the reaction between M(NO3)2·6H2O (M2+= Co2+ and Mg2+) with structure-directing agents (hmta and NH4F). Then, the as-prepared precursor was treated by high calcination temperature under air atmosphere at 550 °C for 5 h, generating the Co3O4@MgF2-f-h sample. In this process, the small particle size of Co3O4 contained in Co3O4@MgF2-f-h are highly dispersed and generate interacts strongly with MgF2 carrier. Finally, the Co3O4@MgF2-f-h sample was then reduced by H2 at 650 °C to obtain the final Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst, which was further applied for the cyclization of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol to produce 2-arylbenzimidazole. 3.1 Characterization of Co-MgF2-f-h, Co-MgF2-f and Co-MgO-h precursors Fig. S1a exhibits the XRD pattern of Co-MgF2-f-h, which confirms the formation of MgF2 (PDF#72–1150) [50]. However, the overall diffraction peaks of MgF2 in Co-MgF2-f-h precursor shifted to the lower 2θ values. This finding suggests a slight increase of the lattice content as a consequence, attributed to the doping with other substances [48,49]. From Fig. S1b, the FT-IR analysis shows that peak around 1000 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of carbon-nitrogen bond (-C-N-) group, resulting from the interaction between hmta and Co2+/Mg2+. As shown in Fig. S1c, the TG-DSC analysis was performed on the Co-MgF2-f-h. The slight quality loss as the temperature increase indicates that the developed Co-MgF2-f-h exhibited good stability. The morphology and microstructure of Co-MgF2-f-h was characterized by SEM and TEM (Fig. 2 ). The SEM images of Co-MgF2-f-h show that the precursors are 3D microspheres with diameter of 300–400 nm are homogeneously distributed (Fig. 2a, 2b). The enlarged SEM image of Co-MgF2-f-h (Fig. 2b) further suggested that it exhibited homogeneous microsphere structure. In addition, the SEM images of Co-MgF2 -f and Co-MgO-h precursors without the introduction of hmta and NH4F showed irregular blocky structure (Fig. S2). The TEM and HADDF-STEM images further validate the microsphere morphology of Co-MgF2-f-h is composed of assembled nanosheets (Fig. 2d, 2e). Furthermore, the EDS mapping images of Co-MgF2-f-h revealed the existence of Co, Mg, F and O elements (Fig. 2f-2i). The corresponding mapping analysis demonstrate that Co species were highly dispersed on the surface of MgF2 carrier in Co-MgF2-f-h catalyst. The EDX spectrum of Co-MgF2-f-h demonstrates that the surface content of Co is low (1.0 wt%) (Fig. 2j), suggesting that NH4F hmta assisted hydrothermal method enhance the dispersion of Co species. 3.2 Performance of as-prepared catalysts for cyclization of o-nitroaniline and aryl-alcohol to prepare 2-arylbenzimidazole As shown in Fig. 3 , it is notable that the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst remarkably promotes the catalytic performance for the cyclization reaction between o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol. At 110 °C, the conversion and yield for Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst in o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol cyclization reaction are 100% and 85%, respectively. The Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibits superior performance for cyclization of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol in comparison to Co@MgF2-f (70% and 42%, respectively) and Co@MgO-h (45% and 22.5%, respectively) at the identical reaction conditions. Hence, various characterizations were carried out to investigate the origin heightened performance of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst for cyclization reactions. 3.3 Characterization of as-prepared catalysts To explore the reason why the developed Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibited higher performance for cyclization reaction than Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h catalysts, the surface, structure, and metal-support properties of as-prepared catalysts were explored by the SEM, XRD and H2-TPR characterizations. From Fig. 4 a, a panoramic view revealed regular microsphere shape for Co@MgF2-f-h. The enlarged SEM image of Co@MgF2-f-h (Fig. 4c, d) further suggested that it has homogeneous microsphere shaped hierarchical structure. The Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst retains the original morphology of Co-MgF2-f-h precursor and exhibits relatively regular microsphere shape without obvious agglomeration, indicating that a 3D microsphere shaped hierarchical structure catalyst (Co@MgF2-f-h) were successfully synthesized. The TEM, HRTEM as well as HADDF-STEM analysis were also performed on the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst (Fig. 5 ). The Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibits relatively uniform nanosheet encapsulated microspheres without any obvious agglomeration (Fig. 5a, b). Moreover, as displayed in Fig. 5c, the lattice fringes with interplanar distance of 0.22 and 0.32 nm were ascribed to the (111) and (110) planes of MgF2, respectively [50,51]. The interlayer distance is calculated to be 0.20 nm, agreeing with the (111) crystal planes of the Co phase (Fig. 5c) [55], which is identical with the following XRD characterization results. From Fig. 5d, the HADDF-STEM images further clearly demonstrate the metallic Co were highly dispersed onto MgF2 nanosheets. Significantly, the highly dispersed metallic Co nanoparticles on MgF2 nanosheets with strong metal-support interaction (will be verified by the following H2-TPR) can suppress the aggregation of metallic Co, which makes for the improvement of catalytic stability of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst during the cyclization reaction process. Furthermore, the HAADF-STEM-EDS mapping was also executed to explore the distributions of Co, Mg and F elements in the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst (Fig. 5e-g). Interestingly, the corresponding elemental mapping images demonstrate that the small size of cobalt species were highly and homogenously distributed on the MgF2. Meanwhile, the high dispersion of Co species with small size on Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst could enhance the performance of cyclization reaction. The EDX spectrum further confirms that the presence of Co, Mg and F elements with the atomic ratios of 1.3, 19.2 and 49.9 at%, respectively. It further suggesting that Co species are highly uniform dispersed in the MgF2 support. The structure of calcinated and reduced three catalysts were explored by XRD technique. From Fig. 6 a, for calcinated samples, the diffraction peaks at 27.3°, 35.3°, 40.4°, 43.7°, 53.5°, 56.2°, 60.8° and 68.1° can be attributed to the crystal planes of MgF2 (JCPDS-41–1443) [50], respectively. For XRD pattern of Co3O4@MgO-h catalyst, the characteristic peaks located at about 42.9 and 62.3° can be well-indexed to MgO (JCPDC 45–0946) [53,54]. The other diffraction peaks at 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 38.5°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.4° and 65.4° can be attributed to the crystal planes of Co3O4 (JCPDS-42–1467) [52]. Among them, the characteristic peaks at 36.9° and 65.4° were assigned to the (311) and (440) planes of Co3O4 crystalline phases. It is observed that the characteristic peaks of Co3O4 for Co3O4@MgF2-f-h catalyst are weak and broaden than those of Co3O4@MgF2-f and Co3O4@MgO-h catalysts. Moreover, for three reduced catalysts (Fig. 6b), the diffraction peaks at 44.2, 51.5 and 75.9° were assigned to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of metallic Co (JCPDS 15–0806) [55]. Besides, the diffraction peaks of MgF2 and MgO in reduced catalysts (Co@MgF2-f-h, Co@MgF2-f, Co@MgO-h) are identical with the calcinated catalysts. The pronounced XRD diffraction peaks of metallic Co for the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst are remarkably weaker and broader in comparison with Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h, which might have resulted from small size and high dispersion of Co NPs on MgF2 support. The above TEM, HRTEM, HAADF-STEM-EDS, and XRD analyses have confirmed that the Co species presented small size and high dispersion in the developed Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst, which favors the redox coupling of cyclization reaction resulted from more exposed active Co species. The reducibility, interactions between metallic Co and supports of Co@MgF2-f-h, Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h catalysts were evaluated by H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 7 ), and Table 1 make a list of the quantitative analytical results. From Fig. 7, the H2-TPR profiles of three catalysts exhibit different features, and were approximately divided into two reduction regions (denoted as region Ⅰ and region Ⅱ, respectively). The low reduction temperature zone at 200–400 °C was corresponding to the reduction of highly dispersed Co3O4, free Co3O4, and/or the Co3O4 with weak metal-support interaction. The high reduction temperature zone at 520–780 °C was ascribed to the reduction of Co3O4 with strong Co-MgF2 interaction [57]. It is obvious observed that the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibits a higher reduction temperature (710 °C) than another two catalysts, indicating that there was existed stronger interaction between Co and MgF2. As shown in Table 1, compared with the H2 uptakes (zone-Ⅱ) for Co@MgF2-f (0.47 mmol g − 1) and Co@MgO-h and (0.43 mmol g − 1), the higher H2 uptake for Co@MgF2-f-h (0.50 mmol g − 1) can be revealed, suggesting that more reducible Co3O4 species strongly interaction with support were generated. Furthermore, the reduction degree (82.1%) on Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst is obviously higher than those of the Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h catalysts (52.4% and 35.5%, respectively), indicating that the developed Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exposes more active sites, which are beneficial for heightening the catalytic performance of cyclization between o‑nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol [56]. Meanwhile, the higher Co dispersion, larger reducibility and strong metal-support interaction of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst allows itself with higher catalytic performance in cyclization reaction than those of Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h catalysts. 3.4 Substrate scope Inspired by the outstanding performance of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst for o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol, the cyclization reactions were expanded to functional o-nitroanilines and aryl-alcohols (Table 2 ). As displayed in 3a, o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol were transformed to the corresponding 2-phenylbenzimidazole with the yield of 85%. Firstly, for the aryl-alcohol moiety, the electron-withdrawing groups (-F, -Cl, -Br) in the ortho position obtained moderate yield of 65–72% (3b-3d), and the electron-donating group -CH3 in the ortho position gave good yield of 78% (3e). For the substituents in the meta position, electron-withdrawing groups (-F, -Cl, -NO2) afforded medium to good yield of 68–76% (3f-3 h), and electron-donating groups (-CH3, -OCH3) gave good yield of 80–86% (3i-3j). For the substituents in para position, electron-withdrawing groups and electron-donating groups were obtained with good yield of 78–88% (3k-3n), furthermore, furanyl, pyridinyl and alkenes also obtained corresponding products in moderate yield of 67–71% (3o-3q), manifesting that the catalytic system is also suitable for the alcohols with heterocycles and alkenes. Finally, for the o-nitroaniline moiety, both electron-withdrawing groups and electron-donating groups obtained corresponding products with good to excellent yield (3r-3w). The above experimental results showed that the reaction substrates with different substituents can obtain medium to excellent yield, further emphasizing that the developed Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst is a favorable catalyst for synthesis of 2-arylbenzimidazoles via the cyclization reaction of o-nitroaromatic amines and aromatic alcohols. 3.5 Recyclability of Co@MgF2 -f-h catalyst The recyclability has considered as a crucial standard to assess catalysts in heterogeneous catalytic reactions [58]. Hence, the recoverability of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst for cyclization reaction between o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol was conducted. From Fig. 8 a, the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst could be quickly separated by an external magnet from the reaction system due to the magnetic property of metallic Co. As displayed in Fig. 8b, the yield of the reused catalyst exhibits no significant loss throughout the five cycles. A hot filtration test was performed after the cyclization, and the liquid phase was detected by ICP. From the analyzed result, a small amount of Co element (< 0.5 wt%) was detected in the liquid phase, suggesting that there were small amount of Co species leached during the catalytic process, which is also the main reason why the yields of 2-arylbenzimidazole were slightly decreased after the five cycles. All of which was consistent with result of HADDF-STEM-EDS analysis towards the spent Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst (Fig. S3) and the H2-TPR analysis of fresh Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst. To further evaluate the structure stability of the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst, the XRD analysis on recycling catalyst was carried out (Fig. 9 ). The crystal structure and diffraction peaks of spent Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst manifest a well-preserved structure with that of fresh catalyst, indicating that the metallic Co in the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst was stable and had no leaching or aggregation during the cyclization reaction. Moreover, the TEM, HRTEM as well as HADDF-STEM analysis were also performed on the spent Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst (Fig. S3). It revealed that the uniform microsphere morphology of Co@MgF2-f-h is maintained, a deeper analysis by HADDF-STEM and HAADF-STEM-EDS mapping showed that the small size of metallic Co was highly and homogenously dispersed onto MgF2 nanosheets. It further confirms that the presence of Co, Mg and F elements with the atomic ratios of 0.94, 16.82 and 47.34 at%, respectively. The EDX analysis indicated the detection of homogeneously distributed Co species in the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst. The XPS analyses towards there spent catalysts were carried out to prove the effect of Co active sites with MgF2 (Fig. S4). From the XPS results of three catalysts, the obvious observed Co signals were detected, suggesting that the strong metal-support interaction between Co active sites and MgF2, and the active sites of Co species were not lost after the cyclization of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol. Notably, the excellent stability of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst for cyclization reaction was ascribed to strong interaction between metallic Co and MgF2 carrier, which is identified by the H2-TPR analysis. 3.6 Kinetic and reaction mechanism Various characterizations have demonstrated that the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibited good performance for the cyclization reaction is attributed to the synergy effect between highly dispersed small size of metallic cobalt and strong metal-support interaction. The concentration-time kinetic profiles during the cyclization reaction process of o-nitroaniline with benzyl-alcohol was recorded in Fig. S5. As depicted in Fig. S5, a decrease in the amount of benzyl-alcohol and o-nitroaniline was observed, while 2-arylbenzimidazole was subsequently found accompanied by successive reaction between o-phenylenediamine and benzaldehyde. When the cyclization reaction was proceeded for 4 h, the reaction mixture content o-nitroaniline (0.0975 mmol), benzyl-alcohol (0.43 mmol), o-phenylenediamine (0.14 mmol), benzaldehyde (0.30 mmol) and the final product of 2-arylbenzimidazole (0.015 mmol). With the continuous reaction, the concentration of o-phenylenediamine and benzaldehyde gradually decreased, which were converted into the final product of 2-arylbenzimidazole. For the whole cyclization reaction process, the o-phenylenediamine was fully consumed, and partial benzyl-alcohol were converted into benzaldehyde (0.277 mmol) catalyzed by the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst. Notably, the reaction time towards condensation cyclization of o-phenylenediamine and benzaldehyde to obtain 2-arylbenzimidazole is 24 h, which is far longer than that of reduction of o-nitroaniline (8 h), suggesting that condensation cyclization of o-phenylenediamine and benzaldehyde is the rate determining step during the whole cyclization reaction process. To determine the possible catalytic mechanism of the cyclization reaction, FT-IR characterization was taken with incremental reaction time periods (Fig. 10 ) [59]. We found that the characteristic peak of the nitro group in the o-nitroaniline start to disappear gradually as time extends, and the characteristic peak of product began to appear increasingly. We tracked the tendency of the reactants and products with classic characteristic peaks of 1628, 1743 and 1653 cm−1, respectively. During the reaction, the peak of the nitro group located at 1628 cm−1 in reactant gradually disappeared. We believe that the o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol are foremost adsorbed on the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst and it is principally via the complicated dynamics and thermodynamics of electron transmission to conduct adsorption activation. In this process, o-nitroaniline is probably reduced to o-phenylenediamine, and amount of benzyl-alcohol has been oxidized into the benzaldehyde. Therefore, at this period the C = O characteristic peak gradually appeared. The new emerging peaks of C = N at about 1653 cm−1 should be caused by the final product 2-arylbenzimidazole. Thus, a plausible mechanism for the cyclization of aryl-alcohol and o-nitroaniline to form 2-arylbenzimidazole is proposed (Scheme 2 ) [60]. First of all, benzyl-alcohol (2a) is adsorbed on the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst and oxidized to benzaldehyde (BA), at the same time, cobalt species with small particle size are easily activated to generate [Co]-H intermediate. Moreover, the dispersed metallic Co with small size on the MgF2 support can expedite the dissociation of [Co]-H intermediate into the active hydrogen (-[H]), which are beneficial for rapidly reducing the adsorbed o-nitroaniline (1a) to generate o-phenylenediamine (OPD) [61]. Subsequently, on the surface of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst o-phenylenediamine couples with benzaldehyde via condensation reaction to form 3aa. The imine intermediate(3aa) undergoes intramolecular oxidative cyclization reaction under the action of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst to form intermediate 3ab, and then further is oxidized to form the corresponding product 3a. Meanwhile releasing [Co]-H intermediate on the surface of Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst, and rapidly re-oxidation dehydrogenation to form a cycle for the cyclization reaction. Furthermore, alkaline earth metal Mg in the catalyst inclines to form a stable d0 electronic configuration, and its configuration allows to build a good catalytic cycle, while forming covalent bonds is relatively stable [27]. Mg also can suppress the generation of coking carbon by-products during reactive pyrolysis and improve the reaction performance [62]. 4 Conclusions An MgF2 supported Co catalyst (Co@MgF2-f-h) with highly dispersed Co and strong metal-support interaction has been successfully synthesized by ammonium-fluoride hexamethylenetetramine assisted hydrothermal method. The uniform microspheres structured Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibited much higher performance for cyclization reaction in comparison with Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h catalysts due to its smaller size of metallic Co, higher Co dispersity, as well as strengthened Co-MgF2 interaction. The higher activity and stability of the Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst allows it a promising candidate for the benzyl-alcohol and o-nitroaniline cyclization reaction. This study may a method to synthesis of novel Co-based catalysts with good performance for other cyclization reactions. coredata.dc:description: A highly dispersed Co-based catalyst (termed as Co@MgF2-f-h) with strong metal-support interaction has been synthesized by using ammonium-fluoride (NH4F) hexamethylenetetramine (hmta) assisted hydrothermal method. The Co@MgF2-f-h catalyst exhibited excellent performance for cyclization reaction of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol. Extensive techniques including as XRD, FESEM, TEM, HADDF-STEM-EDS and H2-TPR were conducted to reveal the reason for the enhanced performance of Co@MgF2-f-h for cyclization reaction of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol in comparison with those of reference catalysts (Co@MgF2-f and Co@MgO-h, respectively) without using ammonium-fluoride and hexamethylenetetramine structure-directing agents. This study may endow a feasible guidance for the preparation of MgF2 supported Co catalysts with excellent performance for other catalytic reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient MgF2 supported Co catalyst for cyclization reaction of o-nitroaniline and benzyl-alcohol
